revision.text:
An '''oil water separator''' ('''OWS''') is a piece of equipment used to separate oil and water mixtures into their separate components. There are many different types of oil-water separator. Each has different oil separation capability and are used in different industries. Oil water separators are designed and selected after consideration of oil separation performance parameters and life cycle cost considerations. "Oil" can be taken to mean mineral, vegetable and animal oils, and the many different hydrocarbons.
Oil water separators can be designed to treat a variety of contaminants in water including free floating oil, emulsified oil, dissolved oil and suspended solids. Not all oil separator types are capable of separating all contaminants. The most common performance parameters considered are: * Oil droplet size (in the feed to the separator) * Oil density * Water viscosity (temperature) * Discharge water quality desired * Feed oil concentration and the range of oil concentrations likely * Feed oil water flow (daily and peak hourly)
== API oil–water separator == An [[API oil–water separator]] is a device designed to separate gross amounts of oil and suspended solids from the wastewater effluents of oil refineries, petrochemical plants, chemical plants, natural gas processing plants and other industrial sources. The name is derived from the fact that such separators are designed according to API Publication 421, February 1990, published by the [[American Petroleum Institute]].<ref>API 421, February 1990, American Petroleum Institute</ref> These separators can be used to separate large oil droplets, typically greater than 150 micron.
== Oily water separator (marine) == [[File:No. 492 Oily water separator.jpg|thumb|210x210px|Marine oily water separator]] The purpose of shipboard [[oily water separator (marine)|oily water separator]] (OWS) is to separate oil and other contaminants that could be harmful for the oceans. They are most commonly found on board ships where they are used to separate oil from oily waste water such as bilge water before the waste water is discharged into the environment. These discharges of waste water must comply with the requirements laid out in [[MARPOL 73/78|Marpol 73/78]].
[[Bilge]] water is a near-unavoidable product of shipboard operations. Oil leaks from running machinery, such as diesel generators, air compressors, and the main propulsion engine. Modern OWSs have alarms and automatic closure devices which are activated when the oil storage capacity of the oil water separator has been reached.
== Gravity plate separator == A gravity plate separator contains a series of plates through which the contaminated water flows. The objective of the design is to allow oil droplets in the water to coalesce on the underside of the plate eventually forming larger oil droplets which floats off the plates and accumulates at the top of the chamber. The oil accumulating at the top is then transferred with some en-trained water to a waste oil tank. This type of oily water separator is very common for many industrial applications as well as in ships but it has some flaws that decrease efficiency. Oil particles that are sixty micrometers in size or smaller do not get separated. Also the presence of chemicals and surfactants in the water greatly reduce oil droplet coalescence, impeding the separation effect The variety of oily wastes in [[bilge]] water can limit removal efficiency especially when very dense and highly viscous oils such as bunker oil are present. Plates must be replaced when fouled, which increases the costs of operation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Useful sites in addition to NSCEP|url = http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/P100DCO8.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=2011+Thru+2015&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%25253A%25255Czyfiles%25255CIndex%252520Data%25255C11thru15%25255CTxt%25255C00000003%25255CP100DCO8.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%25257C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=p%25257Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%252520page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208062142/http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/P100DCO8.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=2011+Thru+2015&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%25253A%25255Czyfiles%25255CIndex%252520Data%25255C11thru15%25255CTxt%25255C00000003%25255CP100DCO8.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%25257C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8%2Fr75g8%2Fx150y150g16%2Fi425&Display=p%25257Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%252520page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2015-12-08|accessdate = 2015-06-03|first = OARM|last = Cincinnati|df = }}</ref>
== Centrifugal oily water separator == [[File:Sigma Oily Water Separator.jpg|thumb|Centrifuge oily water separator]] A [[centrifugal water–oil separator]], ''centrifugal oil–water separator'' or ''centrifugal liquid–liquid separator'' is a device designed to separate oil and water by centrifugation. It generally contains a cylindrical container that rotates inside a larger stationary container. The denser liquid, usually water, accumulates at the periphery of the rotating container and is collected from the side of the device, whereas the less dense liquid, usually oil, accumulates at the rotation axis and is collected from the center. Centrifugal oil–water separators are used for waste water processing and for cleanup of oil spills on sea or on lake. Centrifugal oil–water separators are also used for filtering diesel and lubricating oils by removing the waste particles and impurity from them.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Oil Water Separator Flow Process Description|url = http://www.oilwaterseparatordesign.com/flow-process.php|accessdate = 2015-06-11}}</ref>
== Hydrocyclone oily water separator == An oil water separation [[hydrocyclone]] is a device designed to separate oil from water by the use of a strong vortex. These separators are passive (no moving parts) and resemble long tapered pipes. They typically contain an inlet section, long tapered section and a long outlet section. In operation the strong vortex is created when the oily water is injected tangentially into the inlet end of the separator. This creates a centrifugal force, that accelerates as it moves down the tapered cone. The centripetal and centrifugal forces separate the heavier water component to the outside of the vortex while the lighter oil droplets are forced to the centre. The separated oils are removed through an orifice at the inlet end of the cone and treated water is discharged through the opposite end. The centrifugal forces generated inside the vortex of the better de-oiling hydrocyclone separators are of the order of 1,000 times the force of gravity. This is why smaller emulsified oil droplets as low as 15 microns can be removed.
Oil removal hydrocyclones, or de-oiling hydrocyclones, are very different in geometry, design and operation compared to the more common solid removal hydrocyclones. When correctly designed and operated oil removal hydrocyclones [[Hydrocyclone]]s are very useful for removing both large oil droplets and smaller emulsified oil droplets in a broad range of applications across many industries. The technology has been successfully applied to treat oily water produced in the mining industry, meat processing, dairy manufacturing, petrochemical, oil refining, oil marketing and oil production operations.
== Flotation == Flotation introduces gas bubbles to enhance oil removal. The gas bubbles attach to the oil droplets to increase the rise rate of the oil. Various flotation methods such as [[dissolved gas flotation]] (DGF), [[dissolved air flotation]] (DAF), and [[induced gas flotation]] (IGF) may be used. Typically this separation step is used following a primary oil–water separation step which is able to remove a large portion of the free oil.
== Nut shell filtration == [[Nut shell filter|Nut shell filtration]] uses nut shell media in a vessel to remove oil. Nut shell filters were designed to separate crude oil from oilfield produced water in the 1970s. Typically, nut shell filters are used as a polishing step to achieve low oil concentrations (<10 mg/L). Oil is collected in the interstitial spaces between the media and periodically removed during a backwash procedure.
== Electrochemical == [[Wastewater]] purification of oils and contaminates by [[electrochemical]] emulsification is actively in research and development. Electrochemical [[emulsification]] involves the generation of [[electrolytic]] bubbles that attract pollutants such as sludge and carry them to the top of the treatment chamber. Once at the top of the treatment chamber the oil and other pollutants are transferred to a waste oil tank.<ref>{{cite web|title = Separation and Purification Technology|format=PDF|url=http://www.atmc.umassd.edu/media/umassdartmouth/advancedtechnologymanufacturingcenter/researchandpartneringlabs/environmentalchemistrylab/publications/Electrochemical_Coagulation_for_Oily_Water_Demulsification.pdf|website = www.atmc.umassd.edu|accessdate = 2015-06-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924031315/http://www.atmc.umassd.edu/media/umassdartmouth/advancedtechnologymanufacturingcenter/researchandpartneringlabs/environmentalchemistrylab/publications/Electrochemical_Coagulation_for_Oily_Water_Demulsification.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-24}}</ref>
== Downhole oil–water separation == [[Downhole oil–water separation technology|Downhole oil–water separation (DOWS) technology]] is an emerging technology that separates oil and gas from produced water at the bottom of the well, and re-injects most of the produced water into another formation which is usually deeper than the producing formation, while the oil and gas rich stream is pumped to the surface. [[Downhole oil–water separation technology|DOWS]] effectively removes solids from the disposal fluid and thus avoids injectivity impairment caused by solids plugging. Simultaneous injection using DOWS minimizes the opportunity for the contamination of underground sources of drinking water (USDWs) through leaks in tubing and casing during the injection process.
== Bioremediation == [[Bioremediation]] is the use of [[microorganism]]s to treat contaminated water. A carefully managed environment is needed for the microorganisms which includes nutrients and hydrocarbons such as oil or other contaminates, and oxygen.
In pilot scale studies, bio-remediation was used as one stage in a multi-stage purification process involving a plate separator to remove the majority of the contaminants and was able to treat pollutants at very low concentrations including organic contaminates such as [[glycerol]], solvents, [[jet fuel]], detergents, and [[phosphates]]. After treatment of contaminated water, [[carbon dioxide]], water and an organic sludge were the only residual products.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Useful sites in addition to NSCEP|url = http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/P100DCO8.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=2011+Thru+2015&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%25253A%25255Czyfiles%25255CIndex%252520Data%25255C11thru15%25255CTxt%25255C00000003%25255CP100DCO8.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%25257C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=p%25257Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%252520page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208062142/http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/P100DCO8.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=2011+Thru+2015&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%25253A%25255Czyfiles%25255CIndex%252520Data%25255C11thru15%25255CTxt%25255C00000003%25255CP100DCO8.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%25257C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8%2Fr75g8%2Fx150y150g16%2Fi425&Display=p%25257Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%252520page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2015-12-08|accessdate = 2015-06-03|first = OARM|last = Cincinnati|df = }}</ref>

{{advert|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Panaya | logo = Panaya - an Infosys company.png | logo_size = 222 | logo_caption = | type = [[Privately held company]] | industry = Enterprise Software | founder = Yossi Cohen | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Jake Klein (CEO) | products = The Panaya CloudQuality Suite | services = [[Software as a service]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | members = | num_employees = | parent = [[Infosys]] | divisions = | subsid = | website = {{URL|www.panaya.com}} | foundation = {{start date|2006}} in Ra'anana, Israel | location_city = [[Hod Hasharon]] | location_country = [[Israel]] }} '''Panaya''' is an Israeli software company. The company is a subsidiary of [[Infosys]]. Panaya's products include [[Change impact analysis]], automated code remediation, collaborative [[Test management tools|test management]] and test-execution, and [[Application lifecycle management|ALM]] acceleration. Panaya’s service runs on the [[Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud]].<ref name="ZDNet">{{cite web | url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/panaya-a-different-kind-of-erp-third-party-maintenance-provider/ | title=Panaya – A different kind of ERP third party maintenance provider | publisher=ZDNet | date=7 January 2010 | accessdate=5 December 2014 | author=Sommer, Brian}}</ref>
==History==
Panaya was founded in 2006 as ''ChangeSoft Technologies'' by entrepreneur [[Yossi Cohen]] and is headquartered in [[Ra'anana, Israel]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.menlopark.com/directory-listing/Panaya/331527 | title=Panaya in Menlo Park | publisher=Menlo Park | accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref>
The disruptive technology revolves around the impact analyses of code change, applied in code comparison of [[Enterprise resource planning]] (ERP) systems to help reduce the application life cycle cost.<ref>{{ cite patent | country =US | number =2009216712 | status = | title =Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | pubdate =27 August 2009 | gdate = | fdate = | pridate = | inventor =Cohen, Yossi; Cohen, Mati; Dor, Nurit; Weiss, Dror; Armoni, Roy | assign1 = | assign2 = | class = }}</ref> A first patent application was filed in 2008, followed by an extension in 2009,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.freshpatents.com/-dt20090827ptan20090216712.php | title=Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | publisher=Fresh Patents | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> and a continuation in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.freshpatents.com/-dt20130214ptan20130041886.php | title=Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | publisher=Fresh Patents | date=14 February 2013 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2010, shares of [[Tamares Group]], a [[private equity]] investment firm based in [[Vaduz]], [[Liechtenstein]], were acquired by Panaya as part of fundraising round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tamares.com/portfolio/selected-investments-private/panaya | title=Panaya Portfolio | publisher=Tamares | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, [[CGI Group]], a Canadian [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[information technology]] (IT) consulting company, announced the launching of a new Panaya Practice.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cgi.com/en/cgi-sap-expertise-panaya-practice | title=CGI deepens its SAP expertise by launching its Panaya Practice | publisher=CGI | date=14 May 2012 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2013 and 2014, Panaya laid off more than 25% of the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themarker.com/technation/1.2033661|title=פיטורים בחברת התוכנה Panaya: קיצצה כ-15% מכוח האדם|last=הירשאוגה|first=אור|newspaper=TheMarker|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.calcalist.co.il/internet/articles/0,7340,L-3638946,00.html|title=פאנאיה פיטרה יותר מ-23% מעובדיה - לאחר שהודיעה שתגייס עובדים|date=2014-08-21|newspaper=כלכליסט - www.calcalist.co.il|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref> In 2016, Panaya shut down their Israeli-based sales development and moved them to Boston and the United Kingdom and replaced their CEO.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/panaya|title=Panaya: Overview|last=|first=|date=|website=LinkedIn|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In June 2014, [[Deloitte]] and Panaya announced an agreement to provide [[Oracle Applications|Oracle E-business Suite]] customers the ability to reduce the cost and risk of application change projects.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/about-deloitte/articles/press-releases/oracle-ebs-upgrades.html | title=Deloitte and Panaya enter Strategic Alliance to accelerate Oracle EBS upgrades and deployments | publisher=Deloitte | date=10 June 2014 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2015, Infosys announced the acquisition of Panaya for a reported $200 million.<ref>https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/15/infosys-panaya/</ref> Prior to the sale, Panaya was in crisis and was on the verge of shut down, after many waves of layoffs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-infosys-buys-israels-panaya-for-230m-1001010261|title=Infosys buys Israel's Panaya for $230m - Globes English|website=Globes|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref> In 2017, whistleblowers alleged that there were issues with the company’s acquisition by Infosys and that top executives of the company had personal interest in acquisition.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/another-whistleblower-mail-alleges-issues-with-infosys-panaya-deal/articleshow/57244175.cms |title= Another Whistleblower Mail Alleges Issues with Infosys’ Panaya Deal |last= Phadnisl |first= Shilpa |publisher= The Times of India}}</ref>
==Investors==
Gemini Partners and Benchmark Capital were the first investors to fund Panaya with $5 million in April 2006.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000097742 | title=ERP solutions co Panaya raises $5m | publisher=Globes | date=31 May 2006 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In August 2009, Panaya secured $5 million funding in a series B investment round led by Tamares Group with the participation of Benchmark Capital.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/08/04/idUS136999+04-Aug-2009+BW20090804 | title=Panaya Secures $5 Million in Series B Funding | publisher=Reuters | date=4 August 2009 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In June 2010, in a series C round, [[Battery Ventures]], [[Benchmark (venture capital firm)|Benchmark]] and [[Tamares Group]], invested a further $7 million.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000566121 | title=Software developer Panaya raises $7m | publisher=Globes | date=10 June 2010 | accessdate=22 December 2014 | author=Shelah, Shmulik}}</ref> In September 2010, HPV, the venture capital fund of [[Hasso Plattner]], co-founder of [[SAP AG]],<ref name="businessweek">{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=225290&ticker=SAP|title=Hasso Plattner: Executive Profile & Biography|work=investing.businessweek.com|accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> invested $6 million in exchange for company's stakes. Shares held by the Tamares Group, a private equity investment firm based in [[Vaduz]], Liechtenstein, were acquired by HPV together with existing investors Benchmark Capital and Battery ventures.
In 2013, the existing investors, in a series D funding round led by Battery Ventures and joined by Benchmark Capital and HPV, injected an additional $16 million into Panaya.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000812822 | title=SaaS provider Panaya raises $16m | publisher=Globes | date=8 January 2013 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> The company has raised $39 million to date.
== In news == Infosys on 14 April, 2018 said it has started looking out for buyers of Skava and Panaya which were acquired during former CEO Vishal Sikka's tenure to build a so called software plus service model. The company has written off $90 Million in Panaya on a standalone basis, which is nearly half of the $200 million that it had paid to acquire the Israeli software firm in 2015.{{cn|date=June 2018}}
==Awards and recognition==
* 2013 : [[Deloitte Technology Fast 500|Deloitte Technology Fast 50 List]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://article.wn.com/view/2013/12/03/Panaya_Ranked_Number_13_on_Deloitte_Technology_EMEA_Fast_500_8/ | title=Panaya Ranked Number 13 on Deloitte Technology EMEA Fast 500 List | publisher=Wn.com | date=3 December 2013 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref> * 2011 : ''[[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]]'' Top Global 100 Tech Startup<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pocketinfo.net/2012/01/red-herring-global-top-100-list-2011.html | title=Red Herring Global Top 100 list 2011 | publisher=PocketInfo.net | date=9 January 2012 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref> * 2010 : [[Gartner]] Cool Vendors in the SAP Ecosystem<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/1332119/cool-vendors-sap-ecosystem- | title=Cool Vendors in the SAP Ecosystem, 2010 | publisher=Gartner | date=31 March 2010 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} [[File:Pancake machine (3103888977).jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|A revolving automatic pancake machine|alt=An automatic pancake machine]] [[File:Pancake Machine (7714422220).jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|A Quickcakes pancake machine ejecting a finished pancake onto a plate|alt=A Quickcakes pancake machine ejecting a finished pancake onto a plate]]
A '''pancake machine''' is an electrically-powered machine that automatically produces cooked [[pancake]]s.<ref name="Billboard" /> It is believed that the earliest known pancake machine was invented in the United States in 1928.<ref name="Popular Mechanics" /> Several types of pancake machines exist that perform in various manners, for both commercial and home use. Some are fully automatic in operation, while others are semi-automatic. Some companies [[Mass production|mass-produce]] pancake machines, and some have been homemade. The Happy Egg Company constructed a novelty pancake machine in 2013 in commemoration of [[Shrove Tuesday|Pancake Day]] in the United Kingdom.
== History == In 1928, a man in [[Portland, Oregon]], invented an electric pancake machine that operated by the process of batter being dropped onto a revolving heated [[flattop grill]] from a storage cylinder atop the grill.<ref name="Popular Mechanics" /> The grill was heated using electricity.<ref name="Popular Mechanics" /> The amount of batter dropped was controlled by using controlled amounts of compressed air, which pushed batter out of the storage cylinder. As the batter revolved on the hot grill, the pancake was flipped halfway through the cooking process by a shelf atop the grill. After being flipped, the completed pancake was ejected from the machine upon contact with a gate.<ref name="Popular Mechanics" />
In 1955 in the United States, an automatic pancake machine was developed by [[Vendo]], which used a specially formulated pancake batter mix that was manufactured by the [[Quaker Oats Company]]'s [[Aunt Jemima]] branch.<ref name="Billboard" /> The Vendo machine could produce pancakes "in less than three minutes."<ref name="Billboard" /> It was a semi-automatic machine that performed all of the cooking functions except for the pouring of the pancake batter.<ref name="Billboard" />
In 1956, four [[Racine, Wisconsin]], engineers developed and fabricated two, 5' diameter gas burning pancake machines for the annual Pancake Day sponsored by the Kiwanis Club there in Racine.
== Types and uses == Various types of pancake machines exist, such as those that run pancake [[Batter (cooking)|batter]] through a heated conveyor inside of a box unit, and those that automatically drop pancake batter onto a flattop grill. Some pancake machines, such as one developed by Crepe-Coer, cook both sides of a pancake simultaneously.<ref name="Association 1986" /> Semi-automatic pancake machines also exist, which require some human interaction to function, such as the pouring of batter.<ref name="Billboard" /> Commercial pancake machines may be used in the foodservice industry, in cafeterias and by restaurants, and can serve to reduce the waste of stale pancake batter.<ref name="Billboard" /><ref name="Carey 2009" /> Some hotels have pancake machines that guests are allowed to operate.<ref name="Howie 2014 p. 452" /> They are also used in other environments in a self-service manner, such as in upscale airport lounges<ref name="Lipsey 2015" /><ref name="Plautz 2014" /> and hotels.<ref name="Travel & Leisure" />
== Homemade pancake machines == Homemade versions of pancake machines have been constructed. An example of a homemade pancake machine is one constructed in 1977 by Ken Whitsett of the Ocala Kiwanis Club in Ocala, Florida, which was used for the organization's annual pancake day.<ref name="OSB 1977" /> The Kiwanis machine utilized a hopper filled with pancake batter that was manually dropped onto a revolving griddle.<ref name="OSB 1977" /> The pancakes were manually flipped and plated when cooking was completed.<ref name="OSB 1977" /> It required four people for its operation, and could produce between 750–1000 pancakes per hour.<ref name="OSB 1977" />
== Companies and brands == Commercial and home-consumer pancake machines are [[Mass production|mass-produced]] by some companies in contemporary times.
=== Commercial products === Commercial pancake machines are typically used in the commercial [[foodservice]] and [[Hospitality industry|hospitality]] industries.<ref name="Billboard" /><ref name="Association 1986" /><ref name="Carey 2009" />
Popcake is a pancake machine brand that can produce 200 pancakes per hour.<ref name="Carey 2009" /> Individual Pancakes are produced in seconds by this machine.<ref name="Carey 2009" /> The machine was designed for use in commercial establishments such as cafeterias and convenience stores.<ref name="Carey 2009" />
Popcake is a U.S. company that produces Popcake-brand pancake machines.<ref name="Hotelier Middle East" /><ref name="Popcake" /> The Popcake machine was invented by Marek Szymanski, and as of July 2014 approximately 7,000 of them are used worldwide.<ref name="Popcake" /> This brand has features that allow users to adjust the size, quantity and doneness level of the pancakes produced.<ref name="Lipsey 2015" /><ref name="Popcake2" /><ref name="HuffPost 2013" /> Plates of pancakes are produced in around two minutes time by the Popcake machine.<ref name="Lipsey 2015" />
<gallery caption="" class="center" widths="195px" heights="220px"> File:Automatic pancake machine! (4828960627).jpg|alt=A Popcake pancake machine|A Popcake pancake machine File:Pancake Machine (5574308502).jpg|alt=Front view of a Quickcakes-brand pancake machine, with various condiments atop the machine|Front view of a Quickcakes-brand pancake machine, with various condiments atop the machine </gallery>
=== Consumer products === [[File:Electric griddle.jpg|thumb|A basic electric [[griddle]] with temperature control|alt=A basic electric griddle with temperature control]] Consumer versions of pancake machines for home use are simpler in operation compared to commercial machines, typically involving a basic [[griddle]] and a feature to adjust cooking temperature.<ref name="Cable 2014" /> Consumer machines are typically countertop-sized [[small appliance]]s.<ref name="Cable 2014" /> Brands include the [[Severin Elektro|Severin]] Crepe Maker, the [[Cuisinart]] Griddle and Grill, Swan's Come Dine With Me Party Wok and Pancake Maker, the Roller Grill Single Plate Crepe Machine and the Andrew James Crepe Maker, among others.<ref name="Cable 2014" /> A review of various consumer machines published in ''[[The Daily Mail]]'' recommended various machines per situational uses.<ref name="Cable 2014" /> For example, the Roller Grill Single Plate Crepe Machine was recommended for use with large groups of people and the Severin Crepe Maker was recommended for "technophobes" who prefer a simple design<ref name="Cable 2014" /> The review recommended the Andrew James Crepe Maker as the overall best value.<ref name="Cable 2014" />
In March 2015 in the U.S., the PancakeBot pancake machine received over $141,000 on [[Kickstarter]].<ref name="Kindelan 2015" /> Its target donation request on the website was $50,000.<ref name="Kindelan 2015" /> PancakeBot can produce custom pancakes in various designs, which is performed by the use of pancake batter in a bottle that is moved by a programmable machine arm atop the griddle.<ref name="Technology.org" /> The machine utilizes custom software to accomplish this.<ref name="Kindelan 2015" /><ref name="Technology.org">{{cite web | url=http://www.technology.org/2015/03/13/pancakebot-pancake-printing-machine-that-inspires-playing-with-your-food/ | title=PancakeBot – pancake printing machine that inspires playing with your food | publisher=Technology.org | date=March 13, 2015 | accessdate=August 6, 2015}}</ref>
== Novelty machines == In commemoration of [[Shrove Tuesday|Pancake Day]] in the United Kingdom, a novelty pancake machine was built by [[The Happy Egg Company]] in February 2013 that involved a complex series of steps to automatically produce pancakes from scratch.<ref name="Molloy 2013" /> The machine involves the use of a freshly laid egg from a hen that rolls onto a turntable, which then moves the egg to an area where it is automatically cracked and mixed with other ingredients.<ref name="Molloy 2013" /> After this point, the mixture is poured into a griddle, flipped to cook the other side, and then flipped onto a plate.<ref name="Molloy 2013" />
== See also == {{portal|Cooking|Food|Technology}} * [[Food processing]] * [[French fries vending machine]] * [[Let's Pizza]] * [[List of cooking appliances]] * [[Waffle iron]]
== References == {{reflist| 30em|refs= <ref name="Popular Mechanics">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zt8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA953|title=Automatic Pancake Machine Cooks and Turns them|work=[[Popular Mechanics]]|date=December 1928|page=953}}</ref> <ref name="Billboard">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QRkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA59|work=Billboard|date=March 5, 1955|pages=59, 73|title=Vendo Builds Pancake Unit}} ([https://books.google.com/books?id=QRkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA73 p. 73].)</ref> <ref name="Howie 2014 p. 452">{{cite book | last=Howie | first=P. | title=Seek Your Bliss – The Guide to Spa Breaks and Escapes from Pearl Escapes 2015 | publisher=Lulu Press, Inc | year=2014 | isbn=978-1-326-11092-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z2peCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA452 | page=452}}</ref> <ref name="Association 1986">{{cite book | title=Hospitality | publisher=Hotel, Catering and Institutional Management Association | issue=nos. 75-94 | year=1986 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yl8sAQAAMAAJ&q=%22pancake+machine%22+hotel | page=78}}</ref> <ref name="Lipsey 2015">{{cite web | last=Lipsey | first=Sid | title=An Inside Look at Alaska Airlines' Infamous Pancake Maker | website=[[Yahoo Travel]] | date=July 21, 2015| url=https://www.yahoo.com/travel/an-inside-look-at-alaska-airlines-infamous-124640990902.html | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Kindelan 2015">{{cite web | last=Kindelan | first=Katie | title=Robotic Pancake Maker Has Kickstarter Investors Flipping Out | website=[[ABC News]] | date=March 13, 2015 | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/pancakebot-pancake-maker-dreams-hits-kickstarter-goal/story?id=29620641 | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Popcake">{{cite web | url=http://www.popcake.com/news/alaska-air-a-machine-that-prints-pancakes/ | title=Alaska Airlines – A Machine that Prints Pancakes! | publisher=Popcake | date=July 23, 2014 | accessdate=August 6, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Popcake2">{{cite web | url=http://www.popcake.com/about/ | title=About | publisher=Popcake | accessdate=August 6, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="HuffPost 2013">{{cite web | author=HuffPost | title=Yes, This Is An Automatic Pancake Machine | website=[[Huffington Post]] | date=June 20, 2013 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/20/automatic-pancake-machine_n_3468598.html | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Plautz 2014">{{cite web | last=Plautz | first=Jessica | title=Alaska Airlines Has a Machine That 'Prints' Pancakes | website=[[Mashable]] | date=July 23, 2014 | url=http://mashable.com/2014/07/22/pancake-machine-alaska-airlines/ | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Carey 2009">{{cite web | last=Carey | first=Bridget | title=Pancake machine churns 200 flapjacks per hour | website=[[CNET]] | date=August 6, 2009 | url=http://www.cnet.com/news/pancake-machine-churns-200-flapjacks-per-hour/ | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="OSB 1977">{{cite web | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19771126&id=R59PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ywUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2142,6607290&hl=en | title=Kiwanis Seeking Names for Pancake Machine | publisher=''[[Ocala Star-Banner]]'' | date=November 26, 1977 | accessdate=August 6, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Molloy 2013">{{cite web | last=Molloy | first=Mark | title=Ingenious pancake machine is flipping amazing | website=Metro | date=February 6, 2013 | url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/02/06/flipping-amazing-egg-company-invents-ingenious-pancake-making-machine-3383529/ | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Cable 2014">{{cite web | last=Cable | first=Amanda | title=Pancakes without the flipping hassle: Don't get yours stuck on the ceiling! These high-tech machines take the stress out of Shrove Tuesday | website=[[Daily Mail]] | date=February 28, 2014 | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2570494/Pancakes-without-flipping-hassle-Dont-stuck-ceiling-These-high-tech-machines-stress-Shrove-Tuesday.html | accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="Travel & Leisure">{{cite web | url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-427942900.html | title=Holiday Inn Express Brand Launches 'Pancake Selfie Express' | publisher=Travel & Leisure Close-Up | date=September 8, 2015 | accessdate=7 March 2016}} {{paywall}}</ref> <ref name="Hotelier Middle East">{{cite web | url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-283810594.html | title=Pancake Maker Flies off Stand at Caterer Event | publisher=Hotelier Middle East | date=March 21, 2012 | accessdate=7 March 2016}} {{paywall}}</ref> }}

revision.comment: Add two more citations in Material Systems section
revision.text:
'''Quantum cascade lasers''' (QCLs) are [[semiconductor laser]]s that emit in the mid- to far-[[infrared]] portion of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]] and were first demonstrated by Jerome Faist, [[Federico Capasso]], Deborah Sivco, Carlo Sirtori, Albert Hutchinson, and [[Alfred Cho]] at [[Bell Laboratories]] in 1994.<ref name="QCL1">{{cite journal |quote= |last= Faist|first= Jerome|authorlink= |author2=Federico Capasso |author3=Deborah L. Sivco |author4=Carlo Sirtori |author5=Albert L. Hutchinson |author6=Alfred Y. Cho |date=April 1994|title= Quantum Cascade Laser|journal=Science|volume=264|issue=5158|pages=553–556|doi=10.1126/science.264.5158.553|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/264/5158/553|accessdate=2007-02-18|format= abstract|pmid= 17732739|bibcode = 1994Sci...264..553F }}</ref>
Unlike typical interband [[semiconductor laser]]s that emit [[electromagnetic radiation]] through the recombination of [[electron–hole pair]]s across the material [[band gap]], QCLs are unipolar and laser emission is achieved through the use of [[intersubband transitions]] in a repeated stack of semiconductor multiple [[quantum well]] [[heterostructure]]s, an idea first proposed in the paper "Possibility of amplification of electromagnetic waves in a semiconductor with a [[superlattice]]" by R.F. Kazarinov and R.A. Suris in 1971.<ref>{{cite journal|quote= |last= Kazarinov|first= R.F|authorlink= |author2=Suris, R.A. |date=April 1971|title= Possibility of amplification of electromagnetic waves in a semiconductor with a superlattice|journal= Fizika I Tekhnika Poluprovodnikov|volume=5|issue=4|pages=797–800|id= |url= }}</ref>
==Intersubband vs. interband transitions== [[File:Interband optical transition.svg|thumb|upright|Interband transitions in conventional semiconductor lasers emit a single photon.]] Within a bulk semiconductor [[crystal]], electrons may occupy states in one of two continuous energy bands - the [[valence band]], which is heavily populated with low energy electrons and the [[conduction band]], which is sparsely populated with high energy electrons. The two energy bands are separated by an energy band gap in which there are no permitted states available for electrons to occupy. Conventional semiconductor laser diodes generate light by a single [[photon]] being emitted when a high energy electron in the conduction band recombines with a [[electron hole|hole]] in the valence band. The energy of the photon and hence the emission wavelength of laser diodes is therefore determined by the band gap of the material system used.
A QCL however does not use bulk semiconductor materials in its optically active region. Instead it consists of a [[periodic function|periodic]] series of thin layers of varying material composition forming a [[superlattice]]. The superlattice introduces a varying [[electric potential]] across the length of the device, meaning that there is a varying [[probability]] of electrons occupying different positions over the length of the device. This is referred to as [[one-dimensional]] [[multiple quantum well]] [[quantum confinement|confinement]] and leads to the splitting of the band of permitted energies into a number of discrete electronic subbands. By suitable design of the layer thicknesses it is possible to engineer a [[population inversion]] between two subbands in the system which is required in order to achieve laser emission. Because the position of the energy levels in the system is primarily determined by the layer thicknesses and not the material, it is possible to tune the emission wavelength of QCLs over a wide range in the same material system.
[[File:Cascade transitions.svg|thumb|left|In quantum cascade structures, electrons undergo intersubband transitions and photons are emitted. The electrons tunnel to the next period of the structure and the process repeats.]] Additionally, in semiconductor laser diodes, electrons and holes are annihilated after recombining across the band gap and can play no further part in photon generation. However, in a unipolar QCL, once an [[electron]] has undergone an intersubband transition and emitted a [[photon]] in one period of the superlattice, it can [[quantum tunneling|tunnel]] into the next period of the structure where another photon can be emitted. This process of a single electron causing the emission of multiple photons as it traverses through the QCL structure gives rise to the name ''cascade'' and makes a [[quantum efficiency]] of greater than unity possible which leads to higher output powers than semiconductor laser diodes.
==Operating principles==
===Rate equations=== [[File:3level-qcl.svg|thumb|right|upright|Subband populations are determined by the intersubband scattering rates and the injection/extraction current.]] QCLs are typically based upon a [[Three-level lasers|three-level system]]. Assuming the formation of the wavefunctions is a fast process compared to the scattering between states, the time independent solutions to the [[Schrödinger equation]] may be applied and the system can be modelled using rate equations. Each subband contains a number of electrons <math>n_i</math> (where <math>i</math> is the subband index) which [[Scattering|scatter]] between levels with a lifetime <math>\tau_{if}</math> (reciprocal of the average intersubband scattering rate <math>W_{if}</math>), where <math>i</math> and <math>f</math> are the initial and final subband indices. Assuming that no other subbands are populated, the rate equations for the three level lasers are given by:
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}n_3}{\mathrm{d}t} = I_{\mathrm{in}} + \frac{n_1}{\tau_{13}} + \frac{n_2}{\tau_{23}} - \frac{n_3}{\tau_{31}} - \frac{n_3}{\tau_{32}}</math>
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}n_2}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{n_3}{\tau_{32}} + \frac{n_1}{\tau_{12}} - \frac{n_2}{\tau_{21}} - \frac{n_2}{\tau_{23}}</math>
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}n_1}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{n_2}{\tau_{21}} + \frac{n_3}{\tau_{31}} - \frac{n_1}{\tau_{13}} - \frac{n_1}{\tau_{12}} - I_{\mathrm{out}}</math>
In the [[steady state]], the time derivatives are equal to zero and <math>I_{\mathrm{in}}=I_{\mathrm{out}}=I</math>. The general rate equation for electrons in subband ''i'' of an ''N'' level system is therefore:
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}n_i}{\mathrm{d}t} = \sum\limits_{j=1}^N\frac{n_j}{\tau_{ji}}-n_i\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\frac{1}{\tau_{ij}}+I(\delta_{iN}-\delta_{i1})</math>,
Under the assumption that absorption processes can be ignored, (i.e. <math> \frac{n_1}{\tau_{12}} = \frac{n_2}{\tau_{23}} = 0 </math>, valid at low temperatures) the middle rate equation gives
:<math>\frac{n_3}{\tau_{32}} = \frac{n_2}{\tau_{21}}</math>
Therefore, if <math>\tau_{32} > \tau_{21}</math> (i.e. <math>W_{21} > W_{32}</math>) then <math>n_3 > n_2</math> and a population inversion will exist. The population ratio is defined as
:<math>\frac{n_3}{n_2} = \frac{\tau_{32}}{\tau_{21}} = \frac{W_{21}}{W_{32}}</math>
If all ''N'' steady-state rate equations are summed, the right hand side becomes zero, meaning that the system is [[underdetermined system|underdetermined]], and it is possible only to find the relative population of each subband. If the total sheet density of carriers <math>N_{\mathrm{2D}}</math> in the system is also known, then the ''absolute'' population of carriers in each subband may be determined using:
:<math>\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}n_i=N_{\mathrm{2D}}</math>.
As an approximation, it can be assumed that all the carriers in the system are supplied by [[doping (semiconductor)|doping]]. If the dopant species has a negligible [[ionisation energy]] then <math>N_{\mathrm{2D}}</math> is approximately equal to the doping density.
[[File:QCL wavefunctions in 3QW active region.svg|thumb|left|Electron wave functions are repeated in each period of a three quantum well QCL active region. The upper laser level is shown in bold.]]
===Active region designs=== The scattering rates are tailored by suitable design of the layer thicknesses in the superlattice which determine the electron [[wave function]]s of the subbands. The scattering rate between two subbands is heavily dependent upon the overlap of the wave functions and energy spacing between the subbands. The figure shows the wave functions in a three quantum well (3QW) QCL active region and injector.
In order to decrease <math>W_{32}</math>, the overlap of the upper and lower laser levels is reduced. This is often achieved through designing the layer thicknesses such that the upper laser level is mostly localised in the left-hand well of the 3QW active region, while the lower laser level wave function is made to mostly reside in the central and right-hand wells. This is known as a ''diagonal'' transition. A ''vertical'' transition is one in which the upper laser level is localised in mainly the central and right-hand wells. This increases the overlap and hence <math>W_{32}</math> which reduces the population inversion, but it increases the strength of the radiative transition and therefore the [[Gain (laser)|gain]].
In order to increase <math>W_{21}</math>, the lower laser level and the ground level wave functions are designed such that they have a good overlap and to increase <math>W_{21}</math> further, the energy spacing between the subbands is designed such that it is equal to the [[Optical phonon|longitudinal optical (LO) phonon]] energy (~36 meV in GaAs) so that resonant LO phonon-electron scattering can quickly depopulate the lower laser level.
==Material systems== The first QCL was fabricated in the [[Indium gallium arsenide|GaInAs]]/[[Aluminium indium arsenide|AlInAs]] material system lattice-matched to an [[indium phosphide|InP]] substrate.<ref name="QCL1" /> This particular material system has a conduction band offset (quantum well depth) of 520 [[Electronvolt|meV]]. These InP-based devices have reached very high levels of performance across the mid-[[infrared]] spectral range, achieving high power, above room-temperature, [[continuous wave]] emission.<ref>{{cite journal |quote= |last=Razeghi|first=Manijeh|authorlink= |year= 2009|title= High-Performance InP-Based Mid-IR Quantum Cascade Lasers |journal=IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics |volume=15|pages= 941–951|doi=10.1109/JSTQE.2008.2006764|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=5069088|accessdate=2011-07-13|format= abstract |issue= 3|bibcode=2009IJSTQ..15..941R}}</ref>
In 1998 [[gallium arsenide|GaAs]]/[[aluminium gallium arsenide|AlGaAs]] QCLs were demonstrated by Sirtori ''et al.'' proving that the QC concept is not restricted to one material system.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Sirorti et al. |journal=Appl. Phys. Lett.|volume=73|issue=24|page=3486|year=1998|doi=10.1063/1.122812|title=GaAs/Al<sub>x</sub>Ga<sub>1−x</sub>As quantum cascade lasers |bibcode=1998ApPhL..73.3486S}}</ref> This material system has a varying quantum well depth depending on the aluminium fraction in the barriers.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} Although GaAs-based QCLs have not matched the performance levels of InP-based QCLs in the mid-infrared, they have proven to be very successful in the [[Terahertz radiation|terahertz]] region of the spectrum.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Benjamin S.|date=2007|title=Terahertz quantum-cascade lasers|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nphoton.2007.166|journal=Nature Photonics|language=En|volume=1|issue=9|pages=517–525|doi=10.1038/nphoton.2007.166|issn=1749-4885|via=}}</ref>
The short wavelength limit of QCLs is determined by the depth of the quantum well and recently QCLs have been developed in material systems with very deep quantum wells in order to achieve short wavelength emission. The InGaAs/AlAsSb material system has quantum wells 1.6 eV deep and has been used to fabricate QCLs emitting at 3.05 μm.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Revin|first=D. G.|last2=Cockburn|first2=J. W.|last3=Steer|first3=M. J.|last4=Airey|first4=R. J.|last5=Hopkinson|first5=M.|last6=Krysa|first6=A. B.|last7=Wilson|first7=L. R.|last8=Menzel|first8=S.|date=2007-01-08|title=InGaAs∕AlAsSb∕InP quantum cascade lasers operating at wavelengths close to 3μm|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2431035|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=90|issue=2|pages=021108|doi=10.1063/1.2431035|issn=0003-6951}}</ref> InAs/AlSb QCLs have quantum wells 2.1 eV deep and [[electroluminescence]] at wavelengths as short as 2.5 μm has been observed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barate|first=D.|last2=Teissier|first2=R.|last3=Wang|first3=Y.|last4=Baranov|first4=A. N.|date=2005|title=Short wavelength intersubband emission from InAs∕AlSb quantum cascade structures|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2007854|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=87|issue=5|pages=051103|doi=10.1063/1.2007854|issn=0003-6951|via=}}</ref>
QCLs may also allow laser operation in materials traditionally considered to have poor optical properties. Indirect bandgap materials such as silicon have minimum electron and hole energies at different momentum values. For interband optical transitions, carriers change momentum through a slow, intermediate scattering process, dramatically reducing the optical emission intensity. Intersubband optical transitions however, are independent of the relative momentum of conduction band and valence band minima and theoretical proposals for [[Silicon|Si]]/[[SiGe]] quantum cascade emitters have been made.<ref>{{cite journal |quote= |last=Paul|first=Douglas J|authorlink= |year= 2004|title= Si/SiGe heterostructures: from material and physics to devices and circuits |journal=Semicond. Sci. Technol. |volume=19 |issue= 10|pages= R75–R108|doi=10.1088/0268-1242/19/10/R02|url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/abstract/0268-1242/19/10/R02|accessdate=2007-02-18|format= abstract|bibcode = 2004SeScT..19R..75P }}</ref>
==Emission wavelengths== {{multiple issues|section=yes| {{Disputed section|section|date=January 2012}} {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} }} QCLs currently cover the wavelength range from 2.63 μm <ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cathabard | first1 = O. | last2 = Teissier | first2 = R. | last3 = Devenson | first3 = J. | last4 = Moreno | first4 = J.C. | last5 = Baranov | first5 = A.N. | year = 2010| title = Quantum cascade lasers emitting near 2.6 μm| url = | journal = Applied Physics Letters | volume = 96 | issue = 14| page = 141110 | doi = 10.1063/1.3385778 |bibcode = 2010ApPhL..96n1110C }}</ref> to 250 μm <ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Walther | first1 = C. | last2 = Fischer | first2 = M. | last3 = Scalari | first3 = G. | last4 = Terazzi | first4 = R. | last5 = Hoyler | first5 = N. | last6 = Faist | first6 = J. | year = 2007| title = Quantum cascade lasers operating from 1.2 to 1.6 THz| url = | journal = Applied Physics Letters | volume = 91 | issue = 13| page = 131122 | doi = 10.1063/1.2793177 |bibcode = 2007ApPhL..91m1122W }}</ref>(and extends to 355 μm with the application of a magnetic field.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}})
==Optical waveguides== [[File:QC ridge waveguide.jpg|thumb|right|250px|End view of QC facet with ridge waveguide. Darker gray: InP, lighter gray: QC layers, black: dielectric, gold: Au coating. Ridge ~ 10 um wide.]] [[File:QC buried heterostructure.jpg|thumb|right|250px|End view of QC facet with buried heterostructure waveguide. Darker gray: InP, lighter gray: QC layers, black: dielectric. Heterostructure ~ 10 um wide]] The first step in processing quantum cascade gain material to make a useful light-emitting device is to confine the [[gain medium]] in an optical [[waveguide (optics)|waveguide]]. This makes it possible to direct the emitted light into a [[collimated]] beam, and allows a [[laser resonator]] to be built such that light can be coupled back into the gain medium.
Two types of optical waveguides are in common use. A ridge waveguide is created by etching parallel trenches in the quantum cascade gain material to create an isolated stripe of QC material, typically ~10 um wide, and several mm long. A [[dielectric]] material is typically deposited in the trenches to guide injected current into the ridge, then the entire ridge is typically coated with gold to provide electrical contact and to help remove heat from the ridge when it is producing light. Light is emitted from the cleaved ends of the waveguide, with an active area that is typically only a few micrometers in dimension.
The second waveguide type is a buried [[heterostructure]]. Here, the QC material is also etched to produce an isolated ridge. Now, however, new semiconductor material is grown over the ridge. The change in index of refraction between the QC material and the overgrown material is sufficient to create a waveguide. Dielectric material is also deposited on the overgrown material around QC ridge to guide the injected current into the QC gain medium. Buried heterostructure waveguides are efficient at removing heat from the QC active area when light is being produced.
==Laser types== Although the quantum cascade gain medium can be used to produce [[Coherence (physics)|incoherent]] light in a superluminescent configuration,<ref> {{cite journal | last=Zibik | first=E. A. |author2=W. H. Ng |author3=D. G. Revin |author4=L. R. Wilson |author5=J. W. Cockburn |author6=K. M. Groom |author7=M. Hopkinson |date=March 2006 | title= Broadband 6 µm < λ < 8 µm superluminescent quantum cascade light-emitting diodes | journal=Appl. Phys. Lett. | volume=88 | issue=12 | page=121109 | doi=10.1063/1.2188371 |bibcode = 2006ApPhL..88l1109Z }}</ref> it is most commonly used in combination with an optical cavity to form a laser.
===Fabry–Perot lasers=== This is the simplest of the quantum cascade lasers. An optical waveguide is first fabricated out of the quantum cascade material to form the gain medium. The ends of the crystalline semiconductor device are then cleaved to form two parallel mirrors on either end of the waveguide, thus forming a [[Fabry–Pérot]] resonator. The residual reflectivity on the cleaved facets from the semiconductor-to-air interface is sufficient to create a resonator. Fabry–Pérot quantum cascade lasers are capable of producing high powers,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Slivken |first=S. |author2=A. Evans |author3=J. David |author4=M. Razeghi |date=December 2002 |title= High-average-power, high-duty-cycle (λ ~ 6 µm) quantum cascade lasers |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=81 |issue=23 |pages=4321–4323 |doi=10.1063/1.1526462 |bibcode = 2002ApPhL..81.4321S }}</ref> but are typically multi-[[Longitudinal mode|mode]] at higher operating currents. The wavelength can be changed chiefly by changing the temperature of the QC device.
=== Distributed feedback lasers=== A [[Distributed feedback laser|distributed feedback]] (DFB) quantum cascade laser<ref>{{cite journal |last=Faist |first=Jérome |author2=Claire Gmachl |author3=Frederico Capasso |author4=Carlo Sirtori |author5=Deborah L. Silvco |author6=James N. Baillargeon |author7=Alfred Y. Cho |date=May 1997 |title= Distributed feedback quantum cascade lasers |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=70 |issue=20 |page=2670 |doi=10.1063/1.119208 |bibcode = 1997ApPhL..70.2670F }}</ref> is similar to a Fabry–Pérot laser, except for a [[Distributed Bragg reflector|distributed Bragg reflector (DBR)]] built on top of the waveguide to prevent it from emitting at other than the desired wavelength. This forces single mode operation of the laser, even at higher operating currents. DFB lasers can be tuned chiefly by changing the temperature, although an interesting variant on tuning can be obtained by pulsing a DFB laser. In this mode, the wavelength of the laser is rapidly “[[chirp]]ed” during the course of the pulse, allowing rapid scanning of a spectral region.<ref> {{cite web | title = Quantum-cascade lasers smell success | url= http://www.laserfocusworld.com/display_article/224013/12/none/none/OptWr/Quantum-cascade-lasers-smell-success | date=2005-03-01 | website= Laser Focus World | publisher=PennWell Publications | accessdate= 2008-03-26 }}</ref>
===External cavity lasers=== [[File:QC Littrow external cavity.svg|thumb|right|250px|Schematic of QC device in external cavity with frequency selective optical feedback provided by diffraction grating in Littrow configuration.]] In an external cavity (EC) quantum cascade laser, the quantum cascade device serves as the laser gain medium. One, or both, of the waveguide facets has an anti-reflection coating that defeats the optical cavity action of the cleaved facets. Mirrors are then arranged in a configuration external to the QC device to create the optical cavity.
If a frequency-selective element is included in the external cavity, it is possible to reduce the laser emission to a single wavelength, and even tune the radiation. For example, diffraction gratings have been used to create<ref>{{cite journal |last=Maulini |first=Richard |author2=Mattias Beck |author3=Jérome Faist |author4=Emilio Gini |date=March 2004 |title= Broadband tuning of external cavity bound-to-continuum quantum-cascade lasers |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=84 |issue=10 |page=1659 |doi=10.1063/1.1667609 |bibcode = 2004ApPhL..84.1659M }}</ref> a [[tunable laser]] that can tune over 15% of its center wavelength.
=== Extended tuning devices === There exists several methods to extend the tuning range of quantum cascade lasers using only monolithically integrated elements. Integrated heaters can extend the tuning range at fixed operation temperature to 0.7% of the central wavelength<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bismuto |first1=Alfredo |last2=Bidaux |first2=Yves |last3=Tardy |first3=Camille |last4=Terazzi |first4=Romain |last5=Gresch |first5=Tobias |last6=Wolf |first6=Johanna |last7=Blaser |first7=Stéphane |last8=Muller |first8=Antoine |last9=Faist |first9=Jerome |date=2015 |title=Extended tuning of mid-ir quantum cascade lasers using integrated resistive heaters |journal=Optics Express |volume=23 |issue=23 |pages=29715–29722 |doi=10.1364/OE.23.029715 |pmid=26698453 |url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-23-23-29715 |access-date=4 May 2016|bibcode = 2015OExpr..2329715B }}</ref> and superstructure gratings operating through the [[Vernier scale|Vernier effect]] can extend it to 4% of the central wavelength,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bidaux |first1=Yves |last2=Bismuto |first2=Alfredo |last3=Tardy |first3=Camille |last4=Terazzi |first4=Romain |last5=Gresch |first5=Tobias |last6=Blaser |first6=Stéphane |last7=Muller |first7=Antoine |last8=Faist |first8=Jerome |date=4 November 2015 |title=Extended and quasi-continuous tuning of quantum cascade lasers using superstructure gratings and integrated heaters |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=107 |issue=22 |page=221108 |doi=10.1063/1.4936931 |bibcode = 2015ApPhL.107v1108B }}</ref> compared to <0.1% for a standard DFB device.
==Growth== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}}
The alternating layers of the two different [[semiconductors]] which form the [[quantum heterostructure]] may be grown on to a substrate using a variety of methods such as [[molecular beam epitaxy]] (MBE) or [[metalorganic vapour phase epitaxy]] (MOVPE), also known as [[metalorganic chemical vapor deposition]] (MOCVD).
==Applications== Fabry-Perot (FP) quantum cascade lasers were first commercialized in 1998,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hrc.ne.ch/hrcintreport/createReport?rcentId=2130853200000064531025&lang=FR&order=F&rad=N|title=Extrait du registre du commerce|last=|first=|date=|website=Registre du commerce|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> Distributed feedback (DFB) devices were first commercialized in 2004,<ref> {{cite web | title = Alpes offers CW and pulsed quantum cascade lasers | url= http://www.laserfocusworld.com/display_article/202916/12/ARCHI/none/PRODH/Alpes-offers-CW-and-pulsed-quantum-cascade-lasers | date=2004-04-19 | website= Laser Focus World | publisher=PennWell Publications | accessdate= 2007-12-01 }}</ref> and broadly-tunable external cavity quantum cascade lasers first commercialized in 2006.<ref> {{cite web | title = Tunable QC laser opens up mid-IR sensing applications | url= http://www.laserfocusworld.com/display_article/259939/12/none/none/OptWr/Tunable-QC-laser-opens-up-mid-IR-sensing-applications | date=2006-07-01 | website= Laser Focus World | publisher=PennWell Publications | accessdate= 2008-03-26 }}</ref> The high optical power output, tuning range and room temperature operation make QCLs useful for spectroscopic applications such as remote sensing of environmental [[gas]]es and [[pollutant]]s in the atmosphere<ref name="Normand"> {{cite journal | last1 = Normand | first1 = Erwan | last2 = Howieson | first2 = Iain | last3 = McCulloch | first3 = Michael T. | publication-date = April 2007 | title = Quantum-cascade lasers enable gas-sensing technology | journal = Laser Focus World | volume = 43 | issue = 4 | pages = 90–92 | issn = 1043-8092 | url = http://www.laserfocusworld.com/display_article/289410/12/none/none/Feat/QUANTUM-CASCADE-LASERS:-Quantum-cascade-lasers-enable-gas-sensing-technolog | accessdate = 2008-01-25 }}</ref> and security. They may eventually be used for vehicular [[cruise control]] in conditions of poor [[visibility]],{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} collision avoidance [[radar]],{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} industrial process control,{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} and medical [[diagnosis|diagnostics]] such as breath analyzers.<ref name="Hannemann"> {{Cite journal | last1 = Hannemann | first1 = M. | last2 = Antufjew | first2 = A. | last3 = Borgmann | first3 = K. | last4 = Hempel | first4 = F. | last5 = Ittermann | first5 = T. | last6 = Welzel | first6 = S. | last7 = Weltmann | first7 = K.D. | last8 = Völzke | first8 = H. | last9 = Röpcke | first9 = J.
| publication-date = 2011-04-01 | title= Influence of age and sex in exhaled breath samples investigated by means of infrared laser absorption spectroscopy | journal = Journal of Breath Research | volume = 5 | issue = 27101 | page = 9 | doi = 10.1088/1752-7155/5/2/027101 | pmid = 21460420 |bibcode = 2011JBR.....5b7101H | year = 2011 }}</ref> QCLs are also used to study plasma chemistry.<ref name="Lang"> {{Cite journal | last1 = Lang | first1 = N. | last2 = Röpcke | first2 = J. | last3 = Wege | first3 = S. | last4 = Steinach | first4 = A. | publication-date = 2009-12-11 | title = In situ diagnostic of etch plasmas for process control using quantum cascade laser absorption spectroscopy | journal = Eur. Phys. J. Appl. Phys. | volume = 49 | issue = 13110 | page = 3 | doi = 10.1051/epjap/2009198 |bibcode = 2010EPJAP..49a3110L | year = 2009 }}</ref>
When used in multiple-laser systems, intrapulse QCL spectroscopy offers broadband spectral coverage that can potentially be used to identify and quantify complex heavy molecules such as those in toxic chemicals, explosives, and drugs.{{Clarify|date=March 2008}}<ref name="Howieson"> {{Cite journal | last1 = Howieson | first1 = Iain | last2 = Normand | first2 = Erwan | last3 = McCulloch | first3 = Michael T. | publication-date = 2005-03-01 | title = Quantum-cascade lasers smell success | journal = Laser Focus World | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | issn = 0740-2511 | pages = S3–+ | url = http://www.laserfocusworld.com/display_article/224013/12/ARCHI/none/OptWr/Quantum-cascade-lasers-smell-success | accessdate = 2008-01-25 }}</ref>
==In fiction== The upcoming video game [[Star Citizen]] imagines external-cavity quantum cascade lasers as high-power weapons.<ref>https://robertsspaceindustries.com/comm-link/transmission/13152-Galactic-Guide-Hurston-Dynamics</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051025141307/http://www.bell-labs.com/org/physicalsciences/projects/qcl/qcl.html Bell Labs summary] * [http://spie.org/x32449.xml Optipedia: Quantum Cascade Laser]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Quantum Cascade Laser}} {{Semiconductor laser}} [[Category:American inventions]] [[Category:Semiconductor lasers]] [[Category:Terahertz technology]]

[[File:Electron probabilities in GaAs quantum well.png|thumb|Electron probabilities in lowest two quantum states of a 160Ǻ GaAs quantum well in a GaAs-GaAlAs heterostructure as calculated from [[Envelope (waves)|envelope functions]].<ref name=Bastard/>]] '''Quantum heterostructure''' is a [[heterostructure]] in a substrate (usually a [[semiconductor material]]), where size restricts the movements of the [[charge carrier]]s forcing them into a quantum confinement. This leads to the formation of a set of discrete energy levels at which the carriers can exist. Quantum heterostructures have sharper [[density of states]] than structures of more conventional sizes.
Quantum heterostructures are important for fabrication of short-wavelength [[light-emitting diode]]s and [[diode laser]]s, and for other [[optoelectronic]] applications, e.g. high-efficiency [[photovoltaic cell]]s.
Examples of quantum heterostructures confining the carriers in quasi-two, -one and -zero dimensions are: * [[Quantum well]]s * [[Quantum wire]]s * [[Quantum dot]]s
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=Bastard> {{cite book |title=Solid state physics: Semiconductor Heterostructures and Nanostructures |chapter=''Figure 10 in'' Electronic States in Semiconductor Heterostructures |author1=G Bastard |author2=JA Brum |author3=R Ferreira |isbn=0126077444 |year=1991 |editor=Henry Ehrenreich, David Turnbull |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6ZffQs8hvt0C&pg=PA259 |page=259}} </ref> }}
==See also== * http://www.ecse.rpi.edu/~schubert/Light-Emitting-Diodes-dot-org/chap04/chap04.htm * [[Kitaev's periodic table]]
[[Category:Quantum electronics]] [[Category:Nanomaterials]] [[Category:Semiconductor structures]]
{{quantum-stub}} {{electronics-stub}}

[[Image:fast text.png|right|thumb|Standard international symbol of real-time text.]] '''Real-time text''' ('''RTT''') is text transmitted instantly as it is typed or created. Recipients can immediately read the message while it is being written, without waiting.
Real-time text is used for conversational text, in collaboration, and in live captioning. Technologies include [[TDD/TTY]] devices for the deaf, live [[captioning]] for TV, [[Text over IP]] (ToIP), some types of [[instant messaging]], software that automatically captions conversations <ref name="Interact-AS">{{cite web | url=http://www.auditorysciences.com/ | title=Auditory Sciences | publisher=Auditory Sciences | accessdate= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513105437/http://auditorysciences.com/ | archivedate=2013-05-13 | df= }}</ref> , captioning for [[telephony]]/[[video teleconferencing]], [[telecommunications relay services]] including [[ip-relay]], transcription services including [[Remote CART]], TypeWell, [[Collaborative real-time editing|collaborative text editing]], [[Stream (computing)|streaming]] text applications, [[Next Generation 9-1-1|next-generation 9-1-1]]/1-1-2<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reach112.eu|title=REACH112 - About REACH112|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> emergency service. Obsolete TDD/TTY devices are being replaced by more modern real-time text technologies, including [[Text over IP]], ip-relay, and instant messaging.
During 2012, the Real-Time Text Taskforce (R3TF)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realtimetext.org|title=Home of RealTimeText.org|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> designed a standard international symbol to represent real-time text, as well as the alternate name '''''Fast Text''''' to improve public education of the technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fasttext.org|title=The International Symbol Of Real-Time Text|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
== Use over instant messaging ==
While standard [[instant messaging]] is not real-time text (the message is only sent at the end of a thought, not while it is being composed), a real-time text option is found in some instant messaging software, including [[AOL Instant Messenger]]'s "Real-Time IM"<ref>[http://help.aol.com/help/microsites/microsite.do?cmd=displayKC&docType=kc&externalId=223568 AOL Instant Messenger "Real-Time IM"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312102140/http://help.aol.com/help/microsites/microsite.do?cmd=displayKC&docType=kc&externalId=223568 |date=2012-03-12 }}</ref> feature. Real-time text is also possible over any [[Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol|XMPP]] compatible chat networks, including those used by [[Apple iChat]], [[Cisco WebEx]], and [[Google Talk]], by using appropriate software that has a real-time text feature. When present in IM programs, the real-time text feature can be turned on/off, just like other chat features such as audio. Real-time text programs date at least to the 1970s, with the [[talk (software)|talk]] program on the DEC [[PDP-11]], which remains in use on Unix systems.
Certain real-time text applications have a feature that allows the real-time text to be "turned off", for temporary purposes. This allows the sender to pre-compose the message as a standard IM or text message before transmitting.
== Use by the deaf == Real-time text is frequently used by the [[deaf]], including [[IP-Relay]] services, [[TDD/TTY]] devices, and [[Text over IP]]. Real-time text allows the other person to read immediately, without waiting for the sender to finish composing his or her sentence/message. This allows conversational use of text, much like a hearing person can listen to someone speaking in real-time.
== Captioned telephony == Captioned telephony is the streaming of real-time text captions in parallel with speech on a phone call. This is used by people who are hard of hearing to allow them to have the full benefit of listening as best they can, hearing all the intonation etc. in speech, yet have the captions for those words they cannot hear clearly enough. In the United States, captioned telephony is one of the free relay services that is available to anyone who is hard-of-hearing. Originally developed for use on the analog phone systems (where it requires a special phone) it is now available over IP using standard devices.
== Use in collaboration == [[Collaborative real-time editing]] is the utilization of real-time text for shared editing, rather than for conversation. Split screen chat, where conversational text appears continuously, is also considered real-time text. Some examples that provide this as a service are [[Apache Wave]] and its fork [[SwellRT]],<ref>[http://SwellRT.org SwellRT "SwellRT"]</ref> [[Etherpad]], the editor Gobby,<ref>[https://gobby.github.io/ Gobby "Gobby"]</ref> and most notably [[Google Docs]].
== Captioning, transcriptions and other uses == Real-time text is used in [[closed captioning]] and when captions are being streamed live continuously during live events. [[Transcription services]] including [[Communication Access Real-Time Translation]] and TypeWell frequently use real-time text, where text is streamed live to a remote display. This is used in [[court reporting]], and is also used by deaf attendees at a conference. Also, real-time text provides an enhancement to [[SMS|text messaging]] on mobile phones, via [[real-time texting]] apps.
== Real-time text protocols == Real-time text protocols include [[Text over IP]] (ToIP) designed around [[ITU-T]] [[T.140]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-T.140/en|title=T.140 : Protocol for multimedia application text conversation|author=tsbmail|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] RFC4103,<ref>[http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4103.txt IETF RFC4103 - RTP Payload for Text Conversation]</ref> RFC5194,<ref>[http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5194.txt IETF RFC5194 - Framework for Real-Time Text over IP Using SIP]</ref> and XMPP Extension Protocol XEP-0301.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0301.html|title=XEP-0301: In-Band Real Time Text|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
== Total conversation == According to [[ITU-T]] Multimedia Recommendation F.703,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-F.703|title=F.703 : Multimedia conversational services|author=tsbmail|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref> [[total conversation]] defines the simultaneous use of audio, video and real-time text. An instant messaging program that can enable all three features simultaneously, would be compliant. Real time text is an important part of it.
== History == Real-time text is also historically found in the old UNIX [[talk (software)|talk]], BBS software such as [[Celerity BBS]], and older versions of [[ICQ]] messaging software.
== See also == * [[Collaborative real-time editor]] * [[Text over IP]] == References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.realtimetext.org realtimetext.org - Real Time Text Taskforce (R3TF)] * [http://www.realjabber.org realjabber.org - Animation of what real-time text looks like / Information on XEP-0301] * [http://www.ives.fr/index.php/en/ives/ives-the-company Total Conversation by IVèS] * [http://www.omnitor.se/eng/total_konversation_en.html Total Conversation by Omintor] * [http://www.djanah.com Total Conversation in the cloud]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Real-Time Text}} [[Category:IMS services]] [[Category:Real-time technology|Text]]

The '''SCR-658 radar''' was developed in conjunction with the [[SCR-268 radar]]. It was preceded by the SCR-258. Its primary purpose was to track weather balloons. Prior to this it was only possible to track weather balloons with a [[theodolite]], causing difficulty with visual tracking in poor [[weather]] conditions. The set is small enough to be portable and carried in a [[Ben Hur trailer]]. [[File:SCR-658 radar.JPG|200px|thumb|SCR-658]]
==Surviving examples== There is one known survivor at the Air Force museum in [[Dayton Ohio]].<ref>http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/photos/index.asp?galleryID=4881</ref>
==See also== * [[Signal Corps Radio]] * [[Radiosonde]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * TM 11-1158 * TM 11-2409 mobile Meteorological station * Air Defense Artillery Journal March-April 1949 [https://web.archive.org/web/20120615073711/http://www.airdefenseartillery.com/online/2010/Antiaircraft%20Command%201946/Antiaircraft%20Journal/1949%20Screen/Mar-Apr%201949%20(Screen).pdf]
==External links== * http://www.photolib.noaa.gov/htmls/wea01200.htm * https://web.archive.org/web/20100413132056/http://www.gordon.army.mil/ocos/museum/equipment.asp SCR and BC lists * https://web.archive.org/web/20081121225613/http://6thweathermobile.org/1949_(part%201).htm excellent pics. * http://www.srh.noaa.gov/ssd/tstm/html/tstorm.htm

{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=October 2013}} {{more citations needed|date=October 2013}} {{third-party|date=October 2013}} {{Orphan|date=June 2018}} }} '''SITS:Vision''', also known just as SITS, is a database application used for course and student management in further and higher education institutions, developed and maintained by the Tribal Group. It is currently used by roughly 70%<ref>[http://www.tribalgroup.com/aboutus/news/Pages/PRESSRELEASEOxfordUniversity.aspx] PRESS RELEASE: Tribal provides University of Oxford with market-leading Student Management System</ref> of the UK higher education sector as well as international institutions such as the [[University of Sydney]] and the [[University of Otago]].
==History== SITS has been in existence since 1991 and was first developed by a former Registrar and IT Director of a UK university. The company, Strategic Information Technology Services, started in a residential property in Beverley, East Yorkshire before moving to commercial property in Middleton-on-the-Wolds. The business moved to Hessle, East Yorkshire, in 1997 and into the current premises in Hesslewood in 2000. SITS was acquired by Tribal Group PLC [TRB.L] in 2004.
==E:Vision== E:Vision (sometimes styled as eVision or e:Vision), is a web-based interface designed to interact with the SITS client.
It was created with the intention of allowing users to design web-based interfaces for student and/or staff interaction. This has the advantage of allowing the user to circumvent the SITS client which some customers find cumbersome.
E:Vision interfaces are created using the traditional SITS client, but does not come as a standard component when purchasing SITS. The two basic type of interfaces that can be created are 'tasks' and 'vistas' - the former allowing workflows to be created wherein a user might complete a process or operation, the latter offers an area in which data can be viewed and edited.<ref name="evision">[http://www.tribalgroup.com/technology/sitsvision/evision/Pages/default.aspx e:Vision]</ref>
==Institutions that use SITS:Vision == === In the United Kingdom === * [[Arts University Bournemouth]] * [[Adam Smith College]] * [[Anglia Ruskin University]] * [[Aston University]] * [[Bath Spa University]] * [[Birkbeck College]] *[[Birmingham City University]] * [[Bournemouth University]] * [[Brighton University]] * [[Brunel University]] * [[Cardiff University]] * [[City, University of London]] * [[Courtauld Institute of Art]] * [[Cranfield University]] * [[Dundee & Angus College]] * [[Falmouth University]] * [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]] * [[Keele University]] * [[King's College London]] * [[Kingston University]] * [[Liverpool Hope University]] * [[London Metropolitan University]] * [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] <ref name="lse">[http://www.lse.ac.uk/intranet/staff/ardSystems/pdf/SITS%20Overview%20830.pdf], SITS Manual</ref> * [[London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine]] * [[Northumbria University]] * [[Queen Mary, University of London]] * [[Regent's University, London]] * [[Robert Gordon University]] * [[Royal Veterinary College]] * [[Swansea University]] * [[Sheffield Hallam University]] * [[Teesside University]] * [[University of the Arts London]] * [[University of Abertay]] * [[University of Bedfordshire]] * [[University of Bolton]] * [[University of Bristol]] * [[University of Bradford]] * [[University of Chester]] * [[University of Chichester]] * [[University College London]]<ref name="ucl">[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/media/library/sits], SITS - the perfect fit for UCL</ref> * [[University for the Creative Arts]] * [[University of Dundee]] * [[University of East Anglia]]<ref name="uea">[https://www.uea.ac.uk/is/cis/sits] Student Information System (SITS)</ref> * [[University of East London]] * [[University of Exeter]] * [[University of Gloucestershire]] * [[University of Huddersfield]] * [[University of Kent]] * [[University of London]] * [[University of Leicester]] * [[University of Oxford]]<ref name="oxford">[http://www.admin.ox.ac.uk/ac-div/studentsystems/sits] Tribal SITS Vision</ref> * [[University of Reading]] <ref name="reading">[http://www.reading.ac.uk/internal/RISIS/Aboutus/risis-aboutus.aspx]</ref> * [[University of St Andrews]] * [[University of Stirling]] * [[University of Sunderland]] * [[University of Sussex]] * [[University of the Highlands and Islands]] * [[University of Warwick]]<ref name="warwick">[http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/services/spa/sits/info/] What is SITS?</ref> * [[University of Westminster]] * [[University of the West of England]] * [[University of Winchester]] * [[University of Wolverhampton]] * [[University of Worcester]] * [[University of York]]
=== Outside the United Kingdom === * [[Trinity College Dublin]], Ireland * [[University of Malta]], Malta * [[Massey University]], New Zealand * [[University of Otago]], New Zealand * [[University of Sydney]], Australia * [[RMIT University]], Australia * [[Universiti Teknologi Petronas|Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS]], Malaysia * [[University of Malaya]], Malaysia * [[University of Limerick]], Ireland
==References== {{Reflist}}
